title: Banks know they have a mortgage pricing problem
text:
The whole episode – first Thorburn’s admission on loyalty and then the bank’s subsequent return to aggressive discounting in its front book – underlines the conundrum confronting the banks.

They must know that there isn’t much long-term sense in creating an environment whereby customers churn from one home loan to the next every three or four years, and have regard only for price.

And yet the importance of mortgages to their profitability – which has only increased as the four big banks have moved to simplify their operations in the wake the royal commission – gives them little option but to their focus into selling new mortgages, rather than keeping existing ones.

The current furore over the banks holding back part of the Reserve Bank’s 25 per cent rate cut has put into sharp focus the question of how to address what Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims describes as a “loyalty tax” levied on existing mortgage holders.

As Sims told The Australian Financial Review on Monday, there is no regulatory answer he can think of.

But as Evans & Partners analyst Matthew Wilson argues, the difference between what is charge to new and existing customers – which was put at 32 basis points by the ACCC last year, and at 50 basis points by Deloitte in 20017 – may actually be competed away, as mortgage brokers feel the weight of their new duty to act in the best interests of borrowers and encourage them to seek cheaper loans.

(Lucky Kenneth Hayne didn’t get his wish to get rid of brokers, eh?)

Which raises the question of whether NAB – or any of its bigger rivals – should try to find a way permanently close that gap between new and existing mortgage rates, before it is closed anyway.

Advertisement

That’s a big, complex question. Perhaps a shorter term issue is whether it is time for way the banking sector to stop shooting itself in the foot with the way it talks about its mortgage pricing.

The sector is howling at claims in The Australian that the banks are reaping an extra $14 billion a year in interest payments, a figure calculated by comparing the fall in the RBA cash rate to the fall in average standard variable rate, which sits at 4.8 per cent.

The banks say very few customers pay this rate, with discounts shaving between 130 basis points and 150 basis points off the actually rate paid by most mortgagees.

So why do the banks still quote these average standard variable rates that look so high?

The answer is that they like the lack of transparency, as it allows them to offer different customers with different circumstances different levels of discounting.

Obviously, the banks need to customise rates to account for different levels of risk. But surely in this climate of political and regulatory tension it’s time to find a way to be much more transparent with the community about mortgage rates.
description: Why do the banks still quote these average standard variable rates that look so high? Because they like the lack of transparency.
